Some days I was surprised to realize that the last time I stood up from my work desk was two hours ago.

Other days, I stare at my schedule and feel dread. But it's not that I don't know what I should be doing. Indeed it's quite the opposite, as I actually blocked my time for work in advance. However, when it comes to actually sitting down and start working, I'd rather do almost anything else.

For years I have been contemplating what separates these two states. Is there a procedure to help me enter the first one on demand?

As you probably suspect, I've tried pomodoro, weekly goals, gamifications, etc. Most of them were helpful for a while until they just... stopped working. Nonetheless, each has provided me a hint of what works for me and what doesn't.

## The Monkey Problem

If you've read Tim Urban's [Why Procrastinators Procrastinate](https://waitbutwhy.com/2013/10/why-procrastinators-procrastinate.html), you know about the instant gratification monkey.

It's that part of your brain that hijacks control and steers you toward whatever feels good right now.

The monkey doesn't care about your goals. It doesn't care that you promised yourself you'd study machine learning this weekend. It only sees the immediate: this task requires effort, that YouTube video doesn't.

The trick isn't to defeat the monkey, but rather to outsmart it. You need to make starting so easy, so unthreatening, that the monkey doesn't bother putting up a fight.

## First Attempt: Time-Based Goals

My first attempt at taming the monkey was simple: plan and track a weekly time goalâ€”ten hours a week for studying and side projects in a spreadsheet, then try to hit the target.

There's real merit to this approach. Time spent is a leading metricâ€”you can't control outcomes, but you can control inputs. Put in enough hours and you already see the win. The feedback loop is clear.

For the first two months, I'd check off my hours, feel accomplished, and see genuine progress. The spreadsheet filled up with green cells. I felt proud of myself.

Then month three came with a bit of struggles. For the first time I wasn't able to keep up with my plan cause, you know, a surprise visit from a close friend and then came great time together for a few days.

By month four, the whole thing collapsed. Slowly but unmistakably, every session started to feel like an obligation. I'd look at my calendar and see "Study ML - 2 hours" and feel bored the same way I feel before a mid-day meeting. The monkey didn't just resistâ€”it rebelled.

In hindsight I don't think the problem was discipline. Setting time as the goal made time the enemy.

Instead of asking "what interesting problem should I explore today?", I was asking "how do I survive the next two hours?". I was physically present but mentally checked out, waiting for the clock to release me.

Even worse, when I missed a day, the guilt compoundedâ€”now I owed the spreadsheet extra hours, the deficit grew, and eventually I just stopped looking at the tracker altogether.

Time-based goals had given me a system, but they'd killed the very thing that makes work sustainable: actually wanting to do it.

## The 30-Minute Promise

After growing so tired of chasing hours that I couldn't even look at my calendar, I tried something different. Instead of committing to hours, I made a smaller promise: just 30 minutes each time, and after that, I've earned the right to stop. If I want to walk away at minute 31, I can do that without feeling guilty.

Thirty minutes is nothing. It's one episode of a sitcom. The monkey doesn't even bother resisting something that small.

But that's the trick. The promise itself is what disarms the monkey. You're not lying to yourself about "just getting started". You genuinely mean it: 30 minutes, then you're free.

But here's what actually happens once you sit down.

You pick a specific question to work onâ€”not "study machine learning," but something concrete like "how would I implement a recommendation system for this dataset?". You start with the simplest thing possible: typing out your thoughts. That's it, you start poking at the problem. And somewhere around minute 20, something shifts. You're not watching the clock anymore. You're actually curious about the answer.

By minute 30, you're in the middle of something. The question isn't fully resolved. Oh and what about that other thing? Why it is the way it is? ... At this point stopping is much harder than just continuing.

So you extend the sessionâ€”basically starting another sort-of 30-minute (or just 15[^1]) promise. This flywheel keeps running until you notice that three hours have passed.

Over time, something else developsâ€”trust. When you consistently honor the promise (yes, sometimes you actually do stop early), your brain starts believing you. The next time you say "just 30 minutes," there's no internal negotiation, no suspicion that you're lying to yourself.

Remember that the magic is not about the initial 30 minutes. It's about what happens after.

## About the questions

The questions matter more than I initially realized.

The quality of your session depends heavily on how you start it, which comes down to what question you're chasing. "Work on side project" is too vagueâ€”your mind has nothing to grab onto. But "why does this algorithm converge faster than that one?" gives you something specific to sink your teeth into. Good questions pique your curiosity. They make the momentum build faster and last longer.

The best sessions I've had started with questions I genuinely cared about. Sometimes the question came from something I read the night before. Sometimes it was a problem that had been nagging at me for days. The common thread was that the question itself pulled me forward. I wasn't pushing myself to workâ€”I was being pulled toward an answer.

## Everyday promise

The promise alone has an obvious weakness: without some baseline discipline, it's easy to skip entirely. The solution is committing to at least one 30-minute session every day.

That daily commitment is your floor. It's the non-negotiable that keeps you in the game even on bad days. Some days you'll stop at exactly 30 minutesâ€”and that's fine.

What matters is that you showed up.
